name: moses
title: Moses
description: An a­bridg­ment of the Book of Deuteronomy

verses.translation: Mo­ses summoned all Israel and said to them, Hear the statutes and ordinances that I speak to­day. Learn them and ob­serve them care­ful­ly.
Gᴏᴅ made a cov­e­nant with us.
Gᴏᴅ did not make this cov­e­nant with our fathers.
Gᴏᴅ spoke with you on the moun­tain, say­ing,
I am Gᴏᴅ, who brought you out of the land of Egypt, out of the house of slav­er­y.
Donʼt have oth­er gods be­fore me.
Donʼt make an i­dol for your­self in the form of any­thing in the heavens or on the earth or in the waters.
Donʼt wor­ship them or serve them, for I am a jeal­ous god, visiting the in­iq­ui­ty of the fathers on the chil­dren to the third and fourth gen­er­a­tion,
but show­ing love to thousands who love me and keep my commandments.
Donʼt mis­use the name of Gᴏᴅ.
Ob­serve the sabbath day by keep­ing it ho­ly.
La­bor six days and do all your work,

but the sev­enth day is a sabbath to Gᴏᴅ. On it you shall not do any work: nei­ther you, your chil­dren, your serv­ant, your live­stock, nor any for­eign­er liv­ing a­mong you, that they may rest as you do.
Re­mem­ber that you were slaves in Egypt, and that Gᴏᴅ brought you out. There­fore, Gᴏᴅ commanded you to keep the sabbath day.
Hon­or your parents so that you may live long and that it may go well with you in the land that Gᴏᴅ is giv­ing you.
Donʼt mur­der.
Donʼt com­mit a­dul­ter­y.
Donʼt steal.
Donʼt give false tes­ti­mo­ny against your neigh­bor.
Donʼt cov­et your neighborʼs wife, house, field, servants, live­stock, or any­thing that belongs to your neigh­bor.
Be care­ful to do as Gᴏᴅ has commanded you. Donʼt turn a­side to the right or to the left.
Walk on the path which Gᴏᴅ has commanded you, that you may live, pros­per, and pro­long your days in the land that you will pos­sess.
Love Gᴏᴅ with all your heart, soul, and strength.
These words that I com­mand you to­day shall be on your heart.
When Gᴏᴅ brings you in­to the land that he swore to your fathers Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob that he would give you — a land with large and splen­did cit­ies,
hous­es filled with eve­ry good thing, cisterns, vineyards, and ol­ive trees — when you eat and are sat­is­fied,
then be care­ful not to for­get Gᴏᴅ.
Donʼt fol­low oth­er gods, the gods of the peo­ple a­round you,
lest the an­ger of Gᴏᴅ be kindled against you, and de­stroy you from the face of the earth.
When your son asks you, “What is the mean­ing of the testimonies, the statutes, and the rules that Gᴏᴅ has commanded you?”
tell him, “We were slaves to Pharaoh in Egypt, but Gᴏᴅ brought us out of Egypt.
He brought us out from there in or­der to give us the land that he swore to our fathers.
So Gᴏᴅ commanded us to ob­serve all these statutes and to fear Gᴏᴅ for our good and our sur­viv­al.”
When Gᴏᴅ brings you in­to the land, and clears a­way man­y nations be­fore you,
donʼt in­ter­mar­ry with them.
They will turn your chil­dren a­way from me, to wor­ship oth­er gods.
Gᴏᴅ did­nʼt choose you be­cause you were more nu­mer­ous than oth­er peo­ple,
but be­cause Gᴏᴅ loves you and is keep­ing the oath that he swore to your fathers.
If you lis­ten to and care­ful­ly keep these ordinances, Gᴏᴅ will keep the cov­e­nant of love with you that he swore to your fathers.
He will love you, bless you, and mul­ti­ply you. He will bless the fruit of your womb, the crops of your land, and the in­crease of your herd.
If you say in your heart, “These nations are greater than I. How can I dis­pos­sess them?”
Donʼt be a­fraid of them. Re­mem­ber what Gᴏᴅ did to Pharaoh and to all Egypt.
Donʼt dread them, for Gᴏᴅ is a­mong you, a great and awe­some god.
Gᴏᴅ will clear a­way these nations be­fore you lit­tle by lit­tle. You will not e­lim­i­nate them all at once, lest the wild animals be­come too nu­mer­ous for you.
Burn the carved images of their gods. Donʼt cov­et the sil­ver or gold that is on them, nor take it for your­self, lest you be en­snared by it.
Donʼt bring an a­bom­i­na­tion in­to your house, lest you be set a­part for de­struc­tion. In­stead, utterly de­test it and ab­hor it.
Re­mem­ber how Gᴏᴅ led you these for­ty years in the wil­der­ness, to hum­ble you, and to test what was in your heart, wheth­er you would keep his commandments.

He humbled you, let you go hun­gry, then fed you with man­na, which nei­ther you nor your fathers had known, to teach you that man does not live by bread a­lone, but by eve­ry word that co­mes from the mouth of Gᴏᴅ.
Know in your heart that Gᴏᴅ disciplines you just as a man disciplines his son.
There­fore keep the commandments of Gᴏᴅ by walk­ing in his ways and by fearing him.
When youʼve eat­en and are sat­is­fied, then bless Gᴏᴅ for the good land he has giv­en you.
Be care­ful not to for­get Gᴏᴅ, by fail­ing to keep his commandments, his ordinances, and his statutes.
Oth­er­wise, once youʼve eat­en and are sat­is­fied, and have built good hous­es to live in,
and when your herds mul­ti­ply, and your sil­ver and gold mul­ti­ply, and eve­ry­thing you have multiplies,
then your heart will be­come proud, and you will for­get Gᴏᴅ,
and you may say in your heart, “My pow­er and the strength of my hand has made me this wealth.”
But re­mem­ber that Gᴏᴅ gives you pow­er to make wealth in or­der to con­firm his cov­e­nant.
If you for­get Gᴏᴅ, fol­low oth­er gods, serve them, and wor­ship them, I tes­ti­fy against you to­day that you will sure­ly per­ish.

Once Gᴏᴅ has driv­en the peo­ple out be­fore you, donʼt say in your heart, “Gᴏᴅ brought me in to pos­sess this land be­cause of my right­eous­ness.” In­stead, Gᴏᴅ drives them out be­cause of their wick­ed­ness.
Un­der­stand that Gᴏᴅ is­nʼt giv­ing you this good land be­cause of your right­eous­ness, for you are a stub­born peo­ple.
Donʼt for­get how you pro­voked Gᴏᴅ in the wil­der­ness. From the day you de­part­ed Egypt un­til you ar­rived in this place, you have been re­bel­lious against Gᴏᴅ.
Gᴏᴅ is not par­tial and takes no bribe.
He executes jus­tice for orphans and widows, and loves the for­eign­er by giv­ing him food and cloth­ing.
There­fore, love the for­eign­er, for you were foreigners in Egypt.
Re­mem­ber that your chil­dren did­nʼt ex­pe­ri­ence the dis­ci­pline of Gᴏᴅ; his works which he did in Egypt;
what he did to the ar­my of Egypt; how he made the wa­ter of the Red sea en­gulf them as they pur­sued you;
and what he did to you in the wil­der­ness, un­til you reached this place;
but your eyes have seen eve­ry great work Gᴏᴅ has done.
Be care­ful not to be en­ticed to turn a­side and serve oth­er gods and wor­ship them.
There­fore im­print my words on your heart and on your soul, bind them as a sign on your hand, and wear them on your foreheads.
Teach them to your chil­dren, speak of them when you sit in your house, when you walk a­long the road, when you lie down, and when you get up.
Write them on the doorposts of your house and on your gates,
that your days, and the days of your chil­dren, may be mul­ti­plied as long as the heavens are a­bove the earth.
Donʼt wor­ship Gᴏᴅ in the same way as the nations you dis­pos­sess.
In­stead, seek the place where Gᴏᴅ chooses to es­tab­lish his name. Go there
and bring your burnt offerings, your sacrifices, your tithes, your contributions, your vow offerings, your free­will offerings, and the firstborn of your live­stock.
There, in the pres­ence of Gᴏᴅ, you and your families will eat and re­joice in eve­ry­thing you un­der­take, be­cause Gᴏᴅ has bless­ed you.
When Gᴏᴅ enlarges your ter­ri­to­ry as he has prom­ised you, and you say, “I want to eat meat,” you may eat meat when­ev­er you want.
When Gᴏᴅ cuts off the nations be­fore you, and you live in their land,
be care­ful not to be en­snared by their ways,
for they have done eve­ry de­test­a­ble act for their gods; e­ven burn­ing their chil­dren as sacrifices.
If a proph­et arises a­mong you, and gives you a sign or a won­der,
and it co­mes true, but he says, “Let us fol­low oth­er gods and wor­ship them,”
donʼt lis­ten to that proph­et. For Gᴏᴅ is testing you to find out wheth­er you love Gᴏᴅ with all your heart and with all your soul.
If your broth­er, child, wife, or friend se­cret­ly entices you, say­ing, “Let us wor­ship oth­er gods,”
donʼt yield to him and donʼt lis­ten to him.
Set a­side a tenth of the pro­duce that is harvested from your fields each year.

Eat the tithe of your grain, of your wine, and of your oil, and the firstborn of your live­stock be­fore Gᴏᴅ, in the place where he chooses to es­tab­lish his name, so that you may learn to fear Gᴏᴅ al­ways.
If the dis­tance is so great that you canʼt car­ry it,
then turn it in­to mon­ey and take the mon­ey to the place where Gᴏᴅ chooses to es­tab­lish his name.
Spend the mon­ey for what­ev­er you want, for ox­en, or sheep, or wine, or strong drink. Eat it be­fore Gᴏᴅ and re­joice, you and your house­hold.
Donʼt ne­glect the Levite who is in your town, for he has no por­tion or in­her­it­ance with you.
At the end of eve­ry third year, bring all the tithe of that yearʼs pro­duce and store it in your town.
The Levite, the for­eign­er, the fa­ther­less, and the wid­ow in your town shall come and eat and be sat­is­fied, so that Gᴏᴅ may bless you in all your work.
At the end of eve­ry sev­enth year, can­cel debts.
Eve­ry cred­i­tor must can­cel the loans he made to his neigh­bor. He must not de­mand pay­ment from his neigh­bor.
You may re­quire pay­ment from a for­eign­er, but you must for­give what­ev­er your broth­er owes you.
For Gᴏᴅ will bless you, as he has prom­ised. You will lend to man­y nations, but you will not bor­row. You will rule man­y nations, but none will rule you.
If there is a poor man a­mong you, in any of your towns, donʼt hard­en your heart or shut your hand to­wards him.
In­stead, o­pen your hand to him and lend him suf­fi­cient for his need, what­ev­er it may be.

Be care­ful not to have this wick­ed thought: “The sev­enth year, the year of re­lease, is near,” and you look grudg­ing­ly on your poor broth­er and give him noth­ing. He will cry to Gᴏᴅ against you, and you will be guilt­y.
Give gen­er­ous­ly to him with­out a grudg­ing heart. Be­cause of this Gᴏᴅ will bless you in eve­ry­thing you do.
There will al­ways be poor peo­ple in the land. There­fore free­ly o­pen your hand to your broth­er, to the poor, and to the needy.
If a fel­low Hebrew is sold to you, and serves you for six years, free him in the sev­enth year.
When you free him, donʼt send him a­way empty-handed.
Fur­nish him lib­er­al­ly from your flock, from your threshing floor, and from your wine­press. Give to him as Gᴏᴅ has bless­ed you.
Re­mem­ber that you were a slave in Egypt, and Gᴏᴅ redeemed you. That is why I am giv­ing you this com­mand.
Donʼt con­sid­er it a hard­ship when you set him free, for he served you six years at half the cost of a hired serv­ant. Gᴏᴅ will bless you in all you do.
Ded­i­cate to Gᴏᴅ eve­ry firstborn male of your live­stock. Do no work with the firstborn of your herd, nor shear the firstborn of your flock.
Each year you and your fam­i­ly are to eat it be­fore Gᴏᴅ in the place Gᴏᴅ chooses.
If it has any de­fect, is lame or blind, donʼt sac­ri­fice it to Gᴏᴅ.
Ob­serve the month of Aviv and cel­e­brate the Passover to Gᴏᴅ, for in the month of Aviv Gᴏᴅ brought you out of Egypt by night.
For sev­en days you are to eat un­leav­ened bread—be­cause you left Egypt in haste—so that you may re­mem­ber the day you left Egypt for the rest of your life.
Let no yeast be found in your ter­ri­to­ry for sev­en days.
Sac­ri­fice the Passover at sun­set, at the time you came out of Egypt.
On the sev­enth day hold a sol­emn as­sem­bly to Gᴏᴅ, and do no work.
Sev­en weeks af­ter you start the grain har­vest,
cel­e­brate the Feast of Weeks to Gᴏᴅ by giv­ing a free­will of­fer­ing in pro­por­tion to how Gᴏᴅ has bless­ed you.
Re­joice be­fore Gᴏᴅ; you, your chil­dren, your servants, and the Levites in your town; the for­eign­er, the or­phan, and the wid­ow, who are a­mong you.
Cel­e­brate the Feast of Tabernacles for sev­en days af­ter gath­er­ing the pro­duce from your threshing floor and wine­press.
Re­joice dur­ing your feast; you, your chil­dren, your servants, and the Levites; the strang­er, the or­phan, and the wid­ow who are a­mong you.
Cel­e­brate the feast to Gᴏᴅ for sev­en days, be­cause Gᴏᴅ will bless you in all your pro­duce and in all the work of your hands, so that you will be al­to­geth­er joy­ful.

All males must ap­pear three times a year be­fore Gᴏᴅ where he chooses: at the Feast of Un­leav­ened Bread, the Feast of Weeks, and the Feast of Tabernacles. None shall ap­pear be­fore Gᴏᴅ empty-handed.
Each of you must bring a gift in pro­por­tion to how Gᴏᴅ has bless­ed you.
Ap­point judges and officers for your tribes in all your towns. They shall judge the peo­ple right­eous­ly.
Donʼt per­vert jus­tice or be par­tial. Donʼt take a bribe, for it blinds the wise and twists the words of the right­eous.
Pur­sue jus­tice, and on­ly jus­tice.
Donʼt sac­ri­fice to Gᴏᴅ an ox or a sheep with any blem­ish or de­fect, for that is de­test­a­ble to Gᴏᴅ.
If any­one in any of your towns
has wor­shiped oth­er gods,
and if you hear a­bout it, then in­ves­ti­gate dil­i­gent­ly. If it is true and cer­tain,
bring him to your cit­y gates and stone him to death.
He shall be put to death on the tes­ti­mo­ny of two or three witnesses, but not on the tes­ti­mo­ny of one wit­ness.
The hands of the witnesses shall be first against him to put him to death, and af­ter­ward the hands of all the peo­ple.
If a case is too dif­fi­cult for you to judge, wheth­er hom­i­cide, law­suit, or as­sault, then go to the place Gᴏᴅ chooses,
and ask the priests or the judge who is in of­fice, and they will give you the ver­dict.
You must a­bide by the ver­dict they give you. Be care­ful to do eve­ry­thing they tell you.
When you en­ter the land Gᴏᴅ is giv­ing you, and you pos­sess it, and live in it, and say, “I will set a king over me like all the nations a­round me,”
ap­point a king whom Gᴏᴅ chooses, one from a­mong your brothers. Donʼt ap­point a for­eign­er who is not your broth­er.
He must not ac­quire man­y hors­es for him­self or send the peo­ple to Egypt to ac­quire man­y hors­es. For Gᴏᴅ has told you, “Nev­er re­turn that way again.”
He must not ac­quire man­y wives for him­self, lest his heart go a­stray. He must not ac­quire ex­ces­sive sil­ver and gold for him­self.
When he sits on the throne, he must write for him­self a cop­y of this law, in the pres­ence of the Levites.
He must read from it all the days of his life, so he may learn to fear Gᴏᴅ by ob­serv­ing this law and these statutes,
lest his heart be lifted up a­bove his countrymen or he turn a­side from the com­mand­ment.
When you en­ter the land which Gᴏᴅ is giv­ing you, donʼt im­i­tate the de­test­a­ble practices of those nations.
No one a­mong you is to sac­ri­fice his child in the fire, prac­tice div­i­na­tion, tell fortunes, prac­tice sor­cer­y,
cast spells, con­sult a me­di­um or spir­it­ist, or in­quire of the dead.
Gᴏᴅ will raise up for you a proph­et like me from a­mong your countrymen. Lis­ten to him.
I will put my words in his mouth, and he will tell them eve­ry­thing I com­mand him.
I will hold ac­count­a­ble those who do not lis­ten to my words that he speaks in my name.
You may ask your­self, “How can we know when a mes­sage is not from Gᴏᴅ?”
When a proph­et speaks in Gᴏᴅʼs name and it does not come true, then Gᴏᴅ has not spo­ken that mes­sage. The proph­et spoke pre­sump­tu­ous­ly. Donʼt be a­fraid of him.
Set a­part three cit­ies for your­selves in the mid­dle of the land that Gᴏᴅ is giv­ing you.
Di­vide the land in­to three parts, so that any man­slay­er can flee to these cit­ies.
A man­slay­er is one who kills his neigh­bor ac­ci­den­tal­ly with­out pre­vi­ous hos­til­i­ty.
He may flee to one of these cit­ies and live,
lest the a­veng­er of blood pur­sue the man­slay­er in an­ger, and kill him, though he did not de­serve death.
Donʼt move your neighborʼs bound­a­ry mark, established by your predecessors.
One wit­ness is in­suf­fi­cient to es­tab­lish wrong­do­ing by any man. A charge must be established on the ev­i­dence of two or three witnesses.
If a ma­li­cious wit­ness accuses some­one of wrong­do­ing,
then both peo­ple in the dis­pute must ap­pear be­fore Gᴏᴅ, be­fore the priests and the judges.
The judges must in­ves­ti­gate thor­ough­ly, and if the wit­ness has ac­cused his broth­er false­ly,
then you must do to him as he in­tend­ed to do to his broth­er.
When you go to war against your enemies and see hors­es, chariots, and an ar­my larg­er than yours, donʼt be a­fraid of them, for Gᴏᴅ, who brought you out of Egypt, is with you.
When you ap­proach the bat­tle, the priest shall come for­ward and speak to the ar­my,
say­ing, “Hear, O Israel, to­day you ap­proach bat­tle against your enemies. Donʼt be faint­heart­ed. Donʼt fear or pan­ic or be ter­ri­fied of them,
for Gᴏᴅ goes with you to fight against your enemies, to give you vic­to­ry.”
The officers shall speak to the ar­my, say­ing, “Has any man built a new house and not ded­i­cat­ed it?
Has any man planted a vine­yard and not yet enjoyed its fruit?
Has any man be­come en­gaged to a wom­an and not yet mar­ried her?
Is any man a­fraid or faint­heart­ed? Let them re­turn home.”
When you be­siege a cit­y for a long time, donʼt de­stroy its trees. Are the trees hu­man that you should be­siege them?
You may on­ly cut down trees that you know to pro­duce no food. Use them to con­struct siegeworks against the cit­y un­til it falls.
If a man has two wives, one loved and the oth­er un­loved, and both bear him sons, and the firstborn belongs to the un­loved,
then, when his sons in­her­it what he has, he may not fa­vor the son of the loved wife over the son of the un­loved wife.
He must ac­knowl­edge the firstborn, the son of the un­loved wife, by giv­ing him a dou­ble por­tion of all he has. The right of the firstborn is his.
If you see your brotherʼs an­i­mal straying, donʼt ig­nore it. Bring it back to him.
If he lives far a­way or you donʼt know who he is, bring it home and care for it un­til your broth­er looks for it, then re­turn it to him.
Do the same with any­thing else that your broth­er loses and you find. Donʼt ig­nore it.
Donʼt ig­nore your brotherʼs don­key or ox when it collapses on the road. Help him lift it up again.
A wom­an shall not wear menʼs clothes, nei­ther shall a man wear womenʼs clothes, for Gᴏᴅ detests those who do it.
If you come a­cross a birdʼs nest with chicks or eggs, and the moth­er is sit­ting on them, donʼt take the moth­er with the young.
You may take the young but let the moth­er go so that you may pros­per and have a long life.
When you build a new house, con­struct a rail­ing a­round your roof, lest you bring bloodguilt on your house if any­one falls from it.
When you are encamped against your enemies,
des­ig­nate a place out­side the camp where you can go to re­lieve your­self.
Keep a dig­ging tool in your e­quip­ment so that when you re­lieve your­self you can dig a hole and cov­er your ex­cre­ment.
For Gᴏᴅ walks through your camp to pro­tect you and to de­feat your enemies. Your camp must be ho­ly lest he see some­thing in­de­cent a­mong you and turn a­way from you.
Donʼt re­turn a slave to his mas­ter af­ter he has es­caped to you.
Let him live a­mong you wher­ev­er he chooses. Donʼt mis­treat him.
No man or wom­an of Israel shall be a shrine pros­ti­tute.
Donʼt bring the earn­ings of a pros­ti­tute, fe­male or male, in­to the house of Gᴏᴅ to pay any vow, be­cause both are de­test­a­ble to Gᴏᴅ.
Donʼt charge your broth­er in­ter­est.
You may charge in­ter­est to a for­eign­er, but not to your broth­er, so that Gᴏᴅ may bless you in eve­ry­thing you un­der­take.
When you make a vow to Gᴏᴅ, donʼt de­lay ful­fil­ling it, for Gᴏᴅ will sure­ly re­quire it of you, and you will be guilt­y of sin.
But itʼs not a sin to re­frain from mak­ing a vow.
Be care­ful to do what you say, be­cause you made your prom­ise free­ly to Gᴏᴅ with your own mouth.
If you en­ter your neighborʼs vine­yard, you may eat your fill of grapes, but donʼt put any in your bas­ket.
If you en­ter your neighborʼs stand­ing grain, you may pluck grain with your hand, but donʼt har­vest it with a sick­le.
If a man marries a wom­an, but she displeases him be­cause he finds some in­de­cen­cy in her, then let him write her a di­vorce cer­tif­i­cate, and send her out of his house.
When she leaves his house, she may mar­ry an­oth­er man.
When a man takes a new wife, he shall not go to war or be li­a­ble for any pub­lic du­ty for one year. He is free to stay home, so that he can bring joy to his new wife.
Donʼt take a mill or an up­per mill­stone in pledge, for that would be tak­ing a life in pledge.
If you lend any­thing to your neigh­bor, donʼt en­ter his house to col­lect his pledge.
Re­main out­side and let your neigh­bor bring the pledge out to you.
If the man is poor, donʼt keep his pledge over­night.
Re­turn it to him when the sun sets, so that he may sleep in his cloak and bless you.
Donʼt op­press a hired work­er who is poor and needy, wheth­er he is a broth­er or a for­eign­er liv­ing in your land.
Give him his wages each day be­fore the sun sets, for he is poor and depends on them; lest he cry to Gᴏᴅ against you, and you be­come guilt­y of sin.
Fathers shall not be put to death for their chil­dren, nor chil­dren put to death for their fathers. Each one shall be put to death for his own sin.
Donʼt de­ny jus­tice to a for­eign­er or an or­phan, and donʼt take a widowʼs cloak as a pledge.
Re­mem­ber that you were a slave in Egypt, and that Gᴏᴅ redeemed you from there.

When you reap your har­vest and for­get a sheaf in the field, donʼt go back to get it. Leave it for the for­eign­er, the or­phan, and the wid­ow, so that Gᴏᴅ may bless you in all the work of your hands.
When you beat the olives from your trees, donʼt go over the branches again.
When you gath­er the grapes from your vine­yard, donʼt go over the vines again. What re­mains is for the for­eign­er, the or­phan, and the wid­ow.
Re­mem­ber that you were a slave in Egypt.
Donʼt muz­zle the ox while it treads out the grain.
Donʼt car­ry differing weights in your bag, one heav­y and one light.
Donʼt have differing meas­ures in your house, one large and one small.
Use ac­cu­rate and hon­est weights and meas­ures.
For Gᴏᴅ detests those who are dis­hon­est in such things.
Put in­to a bas­ket some of the first fruit of the har­vest.
Go to the priest.
The priest shall take the bas­ket from your hand and set it down be­fore the al­tar of Gᴏᴅ.
Say be­fore Gᴏᴅ, “My fa­ther was a wan­der­ing Aramean. He went down to Egypt with a few peo­ple, sojourned there, and be­came a great, might­y, and pop­u­lous na­tion.
The Egyptians mistreated us, hu­mil­i­at­ed us, and im­posed hard la­bor on us.
Then we cried to Gᴏᴅ, the god of our fathers, and Gᴏᴅ heard our voice and saw our af­flic­tion, our toil, and our op­pres­sion,
Gᴏᴅ brought us out of Egypt with a might­y hand, an out­stretched arm, great deeds of ter­ror, signs, and wonders.
He brought us to this place and gave us this land, a land flow­ing with milk and hon­ey.
I bring the first fruit of the ground, which you, O Gᴏᴅ, have giv­en me.” Set it be­fore Gᴏᴅ and wor­ship be­fore Gᴏᴅ.
You, the Levite, and the for­eign­er shall re­joice in all the good things which Gᴏᴅ has giv­en to you and your house­hold.

When you have fin­ished pay­ing all the tithes of your pro­duce in the third year, give it to the Levite, the for­eign­er, the or­phan, and the wid­ow, so that they may eat in your towns and be sat­is­fied.

Say be­fore Gᴏᴅ, “I have tak­en the sa­cred por­tion out of my house. I have giv­en it to the Levite, the for­eign­er, the or­phan, and the wid­ow, ac­cord­ing to all the commandments you gave me. I have not transgressed or for­got­ten your commandments.
I have not eat­en any of the tithe while in mourn­ing, or re­moved any of it while un­clean, or offered any of it to the dead. I have obeyed Gᴏᴅ. I have done all you commanded me.
Look down from heav­en, your ho­ly hab­i­ta­tion, and bless your peo­ple Israel and the land you have giv­en us, as you swore to our fathers, a land flow­ing with milk and hon­ey.”
